This is awesome! Just a thought... you could make the install a bit more sexy by wrapping it in winrar or by using one of the self-install software packages. I'm sure a great number of students and young scholars would get advantage out of this, but not many linguists nor humanities students might have a good handle on copying a shortcut to their desktop or program list.
Thanks loads. I'm a teacher AND I use technology. This'll come in handy whenever I do a history study on verbiage and linguistics.

Unfortunately, it seems to only contain the en-US spellings for some words, particularly those ending in -ize instead of -ise, as in en-GB and en-AU. Not sure why that is, since it seems to contain the correct spellings for other words. But it means looking up words like "organise" and "realise" need to be done with the annoying US spelling.

I'm running Win XP, and I had to follow 'mmeirbiers' advice and download msvcr71.dll from dll-files.com and put it in the program folder. After doing that everything is OK. Thanks mmeirbiers!

PS. 'boydaplis' complained that this dictionary is a waste of time, and you couldn't even find "dyslexia" and "dyslexic". Well, I had to check it out, and this is what I found:

dys'lexia [Gr. ?speaking? (here taken in sense ?reading?), first formed as G. dyslexie (R. Berlin 1883, in Med. Correspondenz-Blatt des W체rttemberg. 채rztl. Landesvereins LIII. 209)], a difficulty in reading due to affection of the brain; spec. = word-blindness (word n. 29); hence dys'lectic, dys'lexic adjs. and ns.

I'm running XP SP3, extracts fine using 7-Zip (no password), and I ran this without needing extra DLLs. Avira Antivirus and SUPERAntiSpyware (updated to 2011.02.04) did not pick up any viruses/malware.

Just extract to e.g. C:\Program Files\OED and run SWHX.EXE. This version has a _much_ improved and less buggy interface than the previous version.

how I got it to work (using Win 7 32bit):

1. open in winrar (it didn't ask for a password)
2. rename the folder from "Oxford English Dictionary - 2nd Ed. Vers.4.0 (2009) (Malestrom..." to  "Oxford English Dictionary" exactly
3. extract to desktop
4. drag extracted folder to program files
5. open the folder and look for "swhx.exe"
6. right click, create short cut from the start menu
7. launch program from start menu

 curate ut valeatis, my linguist friends
p.s. I will love you forever malestrom
